questions.text: The vaginal artery in females is replaced by which of the following in males:
questions.solution:
• The vaginal artery is replaced by the inferior vesical artery in males.
  • In males, the inferior vesical artery is a pelvic branch of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery, while in females it arises from the vaginal artery.
  • In males, the main function of the inferior vesical artery is to supply blood for the fundus and neck of the male urinary bladder, prostate, seminal vesicles, ductus deferens, urethraand ureter. In females, when present, it supplies the urinary bladder.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • The vaginal artery is replaced by the inferior vesical artery in males.
  • main function of the inferior vesical artery is to supply blood for the fundus and neck of the male urinary bladder, prostate, seminal vesicles, ductus deferens, urethraand ureter. In females, when present, it supplies the urinary bladder.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence of the arterial distribution in theuterus?
questions.solution:
• The uterine artery gives rise to branches, which run transversely and pass into the myometrium. These are known as the arcuate arteries.
  • From the arcuate vessels, branches known as the radial arteries arise at right angles.
  • They reach the basal layers of endometrium where they are termed as the basal arteries.
  • From the basal arteries, spiral and straight arterioles of the endometrium are derived.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

questions.text: All of the following are the contents of superficial perineal pouch, except:
questions.solution:
• Superficial perineal pouch is a potential space between the perineal membrane superiorly, and the perineal fascia inferiorly. It exists superficial to the perineal membrane.
  • It contains the erectile tissues that form the penis and clitoris, and three muscles the ischiocavernosus, bulbospongiosus and superficial transverse perineal muscles.
  • The greater vestibular glands (Bartholin's glands) are also located in the superficial perineal pouch.
  • EUS or sphincter urethrae is a content of deep perineal pouch.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

Contents of deep perineal pouch can be remembered by the following mnemonic

BUDDInGS-

Bulbourethral glands of Cowper (Males)

Urethra (Membranous part)

Deep transversus perinei

Dorsal nerve of clitoris/penis

Internal pudendal vessels

VaGina (females)

Sphincter urethrae

questions.text: The muscles of the urogenital diaphragm include all of the following, except:
questions.solution:
a) Superficial transversus perinei

Correct. The superficial transversus perinei muscle is part of the urogenital diaphragm. It helps support the pelvic floor and is involved in maintaining the integrity of the pelvic organs.

b) Levator ani

Incorrect. The levator ani muscle is not part of the urogenital diaphragm. It is a component of the pelvic diaphragm, which forms the floor of the pelvis and supports the pelvic organs. It is distinct from the urogenital diaphragm, which is located in the perineum and primarily supports the urogenital structures.

c) Bulbospongiosus muscle

Correct. The bulbospongiosus muscle is part of the urogenital diaphragm. It covers the bulb of the penis in males and the vestibular bulbs in females, contributing to the support and function of the external genitalia.

d) Ischiocavernosus muscle

Correct. The ischiocavernosus muscle is also part of the urogenital diaphragm. It helps in maintaining erection by compressing the crus of the penis or clitoris, which aids in the engorgement of the erectile tissues.

The levator ani muscle is more appropriately associated with the pelvic diaphragm, which supports the pelvic cavity and is involved in maintaining pelvic organ positioning, rather than the urogenital diaphragm.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrectly matched with its developmental origin?
questions.solution:
a. Clitoris - Genital tubercle

Correct. The clitoris develops from the genital tubercle, which is a structure that appears during early fetal development and gives rise to the clitoris in females and the penis in males.

b. Labia minora - Genital fold

Correct. The labia minora develop from the genital folds (also known as labioscrotal folds), which in females form the inner labia. In males, these folds fuse to form the scrotum.

c. Labia majora - Genital swelling

Correct. The labia majora develop from the genital swellings (also known as labioscrotal swellings), which are paired structures that contribute to the formation of the external genitalia. In males, these swellings fuse to form the scrotum.

d. Urogenital sinus - Vestibule

Incorrect. The urogenital sinus is a structure in embryonic development that gives rise to several structures in the adult female, including the bladder, urethra, and part of the vagina. The vestibule of the vagina, however, develops from the paramesonephric ducts (Müllerian ducts) and not directly from the urogenital sinus.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

choices.text: These are homologous to Cowper's glands in males
Located in the deep perineal pouch
Exudes alkaline secretions to lubricate vagina
Duct is lined by columnar epithelium

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding the structure (pointed with an arrow) in the figure shown below, except:
questions.solution:
Bartholin's glands are not located in the deep perineal pouch; they are situated in the superficial perineal pouch. Specifically, they are located bilaterally at the posterior aspect of the vaginal opening, just beneath the vaginal mucosa.

Option A. These are homologous to Cowper's glands in males

Correct. Bartholin's glands in females are homologous to Cowper's glands (bulbourethral glands) in males. Both sets of glands are involved in the production of lubricating secretions.

Option C. Exudes alkaline secretions to lubricate vagina

Correct. Bartholin's glands secrete a mucous, alkaline fluid that helps to lubricate the vaginal vestibule during sexual arousal.

Option D. Duct is lined by columnar epithelium which facilitates the secretion and transport of the glandular fluid to the vaginal vestibule.

KEY TAKEAWAY:-

Bartholin glands are located in the superficial perineal pouch.

Homologous to Cowper's gland.

Secrete alkaline secretions.

questions.text: A 17 year old girl presents to gynaec OPD with pain and swelling in the genital region. On examination, the swelling is red, tender to touch and looks like the image given below. Which of the following is the most common causative agent of this pathology?
questions.solution:
• The girl is suffering from Bartholin's abscess.
  • Escherichia coli was the most common (43.6%), followed by staph. aureus (6.4%), group B streptococci (4.8%), and Enterococcus spp. (4.8%). Less than 10% of cases were polymicrobial in origin.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

E.coli is most common organism associated with bartholin abscess.

questions.text: Identify the following artery (marked by the yellow arrow):
questions.solution:
Sampson's artery

  • The artery of the round ligament of the uterus is also known as Sampson's artery.
  • It runs under, and supplies, the round ligament of the uterus
  • It was originally named after John A. Sampson, an American gynecologist who studied endometriosis.

Kocher's Artery

  • Definition: Kocher's artery is a branch of the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) that supplies the medial aspect of the occipital lobe and parts of the parietal lobe.

Artery of Percheron

  • Definition: The artery of Percheron is a rare variant of the brain's blood supply, typically a single dominant branch of the PCA that supplies both the thalami. It is named after the French neurologist Pierre Percheron.

Artery of Charcot

  • Definition: The artery of Charcot, also known as the "Charcot's artery," is a term that is sometimes used to refer to a branch of the PCA or to the perforating arteries supplying the basal ganglia.
  • It plays a role in supplying the deep structures of the brain, including parts of the basal ganglia.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

choices.text: It is formed from the dorsal rami of S2-4 spinal nerves
It courses between the piriformis and coccygeus muscles
When injecting local anesthetic at the time of nerve block, the ischial spine serves an identifiable landmark
It may be at risk of stretch injury during downward displacement of the pelvic floor during childbirth

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding the structure shown below (with a yellow arrow), except:
questions.solution:
• The pudendal nervecarries motor and sensory axons arising from the ventral (& not dorsal) rami of the sacral spinal nerves S2-S4.
  • It courses between the piriformis and coccygeus muscles and exits through the greater sciatic foramen at a location posterior to the sacrospinous ligament and just medial to the ischial spine.
  • Thus, when injecting local anesthetic for a pudendal nerve block, the ischial spine serves an identifiable landmark.
  • In general, the pudendal nerve is relatively fixed as it courses behind the sacrospinous ligament and within the pudendal canal. Accordingly, it may be at risk of stretch injury during downward displacement of the pelvic floor during childbirth.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • Parasympathetic innervation to the pelvic organs derives rom spinal levels S2 through S4
  • For the cervix and upper part of the birth canal, sensory nerves pass through the pelvic splanchnic nerves to the second, third, and fourth sacral nerves.
  • Last, those from the lower portion of the birth canal pass primarily through the pudendal nerve. Anesthetic blocks used during delivery target these levels of innervation

questions.text: Main lymphatic drainage of ovaries goes to which group of lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
• The main lymphatic drainage from ovaries goes to para-aortic lymph nodes,depicted by A.
  • B, C & D are internal iliac, external iliac & superficial inguinal LN respectively.

KEY TAKEAWAY:-

Lymphatic drainage from ovaries: -

questions.text: What does the infundibulopelvic ligament of the ovary contain?
questions.solution:
• The suspensory ligament of the ovary, also infundibulopelvic ligament is a fold of peritoneum that extends out from the ovaryto the wall of the pelvis.
  • It contains the ovarian artery, ovarian vein, ovarian nerve plexus, and lymphatic vessels.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • Suapensory ligament of ovary contains the ovarian artery, ovarian vein, ovarian nerve plexus, and lymphatic vessels.

questions.text: Which of the following plays a major role in keeping the uterus in an anteverted position?
questions.solution:
• The major ligaments that support the uterus include the round ligament, transverse cervical ligament (cardinal ligament), uterosacral ligament, and broad ligament.
  • The cardinal ligament reaches from the cervix to the sidewall of the pelvis and appears at the base of the broad ligament.
  • The uterosacral ligament plays a major role in keeping the uterus in the anteverted position. It extends from the cervix to the sacrum and supports the uterus posteriorly.
  • The pubocervical ligament provides anterior support to the uterus, helping to prevent cystocele.
  • The broad ligament is a double folding of the peritoneum, divided into four regions composed of the mesosalpinx, mesovarium, mesometrium, and the suspensory ligament of the ovary. It overlies the ovaries, uterus and fallopian tubes, and secures the uterus laterally to the sidewall of the pelvis.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

Uterosacral ligament originates with a posterolateral attachment to the supravaginal portion of the cervix and inserts into the fascia over the sacrum, with some variations.

Keeps the uterus in anteversion.

choices.text: Complete failure of fusion of paramesonephric ducts
Partial failure of fusion of paramesonephric ducts
Failure of a paramesonephric duct to develop
Failure of urogenital sinus to develop

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the clinic after multiple first-trimester spontaneous abortions. She has no significant past medical history and is not currently taking any medications. After undergoing hysterosalpingography, she is diagnosed with bicornuate uterus. What is the underlying embryologic defect that led to this condition?
questions.solution:
In this condition, the uterus has a partially divided cavity, leading to the formation of two horns.

a. Complete failure of fusion of paramesonephric ducts

This would result in a condition known as a uterus didelphys, where there are two separate uterine cavities, each with its own cervix.

c. Failure of a paramesonephric duct to develop

This would lead to a condition such as unicornuate uterus, where only one Müllerian duct develops properly, and the other fails to form, resulting in a single uterine horn.

d. Failure of urogenital sinus to develop

This would not be directly related to a bicornuate uterus. The urogenital sinus affects the development of the lower part of the reproductive tract and does not directly result in a bicornuate uterus.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • Didelphys anomaly arises from incomplete fusion that results in two entirely separate hemiuteri, two cervices, and usually two vaginas or a longitudinal vaginal septum (see 3-5).
  • Uterine didelphys may be isolated or part o a rare triad with an obstructed hemivagina and ipsilateral renal agenesis (OHVIRA), also known as Herlyn-Werner-Wunderlich syn-drome.

choices.text: Concomitant abnormalities of the renal, skeletal, and auditory systems may exist
Ova can be retrieved for in vitro fertilization (IVF) in a surrogate mother

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding MRKH syndrome, except:
questions.solution:
While women with MRKH syndrome can use their ova for IVF, they cannot carry a pregnancy themselves due to the absence of a functional uterus. Therefore, childbearing in the traditional sense is not possible for them.

Here is an explanation of each option:

a. Functional vagina can be created

This is true. In MRKH syndrome, surgical techniques or vaginal dilators can be used to create a functional vagina if it is not present.

b. Concomitant abnormalities of the renal, skeletal, and auditory systems may exist

This is also true. MRKH syndrome can be associated with other abnormalities, such as renal agenesis or dysgenesis, skeletal anomalies, and sometimes auditory system issues.

c. Ova can be retrieved for in vitro fertilization (IVF) in a surrogate mother

This is true as well. Women with MRKH syndrome usually have normal ovarian function and can produce ova. These ova can be retrieved and used for IVF with a surrogate mother to achieve pregnancy.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome is a congenital condition characterized by the absence or underdevelopment of the uterus and the upper two-thirds of the vagina, while the external genitalia and ovaries are typically normal.

  • With MRKH syndrome, a unctional vagina can be created, but uterine agenesis proscribes childbearing.
  • In these women, however, ova can be retrieved or in vitro ertilization (IVF) and carriage by a surrogate mother

questions.text: Which of the following Mullerian anomalies is a part of the Herlyn-Werner-Wunderlich syndrome?
questions.solution:
This is a complete duplication of the uterus, resulting in two separate uterine cavities and often two cervices. It is a hallmark of Herlyn-Werner-Wunderlich syndrome, which includes this anomaly along with other features such as vaginal obstruction and renal anomalies.

a. Arcuate uterus

This anomaly is characterized by a slight indentation at the top of the uterine cavity but is generally not associated with significant reproductive problems. It is not a feature of Herlyn-Werner-Wunderlich syndrome.

c. Bicornuate uterus

A bicornuate uterus is a uterus that is divided into two horns but has a single cervix. This condition is due to partial fusion of the Mullerian ducts and is not associated with Herlyn-Werner-Wunderlich syndrome.

d. Septate uterus

A septate uterus has a septum dividing the uterine cavity into two parts. It results from incomplete resorption of the uterovaginal septum. This anomaly is not part of Herlyn-Werner-Wunderlich syndrome, which is primarily associated with a uterus didelphys.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

Uterine didelphys may be isolated or part of a triad that has an obstructed hemivagina and ipsilateral renal agenesis (OHVIRA), also known as Herlyn-Werner-Wunderlich syndrome.

choices.text: During the second trimester, these contractions can be detected by bimanual examination
Intensity varies between 5 and 25 mm Hg
Late in pregnancy, these contractions may cause discomfort and account for true labour

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding BRAXTON-HICKS contractions, except:
questions.solution:
Braxton-Hicks contractions are false labor contractions. While they can cause discomfort in late pregnacy, they do not lead to true labor.

Option-wise explanation:

a) During the second trimester, these contractions can be detected by bimanual examination:

b) Intensity varies between 5 and 25 mm Hg:

d) They are non-rhythmic, sporadic & unpredictable:

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

choices.text: Prolactin release is increased during sleep
Dopamine acts as Prolactin Inhibitory Factor

questions.text: Prolactin is a polypeptide hormone secreted by the anterior pituitary. Which of the following statements does not hold true for this hormone?
questions.solution:
a) It consists of 196 amino acids

Incorrect. Prolactin is actually a polypeptide hormone that consists of 199 amino acids, not 196.

b) Prolactin release is increased during sleep

Correct. Prolactin levels naturally increase during sleep, especially during the early morning hours (peak during REM sleep).

c) Dopamine acts as Prolactin Inhibitory Factor

Correct. Dopamine is the primary prolactin inhibitory factor (PIF). It is secreted by the hypothalamus and inhibits the secretion of prolactin by binding to dopamine receptors in the anterior pituitary.

d) TRH increases prolactin secretion

Correct. Thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) can stimulate the release of prolactin from the anterior pituitary. This mechanism is sometimes seen in patients with hypothyroidism, where elevated TRH levels can lead to hyperprolactinemia.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • The principal function of maternal prolactin is to ensure lactation.
  • Early in pregnancy, prolactin acts to initiate DNA synthesis and mitosis of glandular epithelial cells and presecretory alveolar cells of the breast.
  • Prolactin also augments the number of estrogen and prolactin receptors in these cells.
  • Prolactin promotes mammary alveolar cell RNA synthesis, galactopoiesis, and production of casein, lactalbumin, lactose, and lipids

questions.text: During pregnancy iodine requirement increases by about:
questions.solution:
• During pregnancy, iodine requirements increase by about 50% due to the increased production of maternal thyroid hormones, the transfer of iodine to the fetus, and increased renal clearance.
  • Adequate iodine is essential to support both the mother's and fetus's thyroid function, which is critical for fetal development, particularly brain development.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

Because of greater thyroid hormone production, fetal iodine requirements, and augmented renal clearance, dietary iodine needs are higher during normal gestation

choices.text: Q waves in lead II, III & avF
Inverted T wave in lead III
Absent P wave in lead I & avF

questions.text: A 32 year old G2P1L1 woman with previous LSCS presents at 39 weeks of gestation. The baby is in breech and she is planned for an elective LSCS. As a part of her pre-anaesthetic workup an ECG is performed. Which of the following ECG changes is most commonly found in pregnant women?
questions.solution:
As the diaphragm becomes progressively elevated, the heart is displaced to the left and upward and is rotated on its long axis.


KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • Most common is slight left-axis deviation due to the altered heart position.
  • Q waves in leads II, III, and avF and
  • Flat or inverted T waves in leads HI and V1-V3 also may be seen

questions.text: Which of the following respiratory parameters is almost unchanged in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• Of physiological lung changes, functional residual capacity (FRC) decreases by approximately 20 to 30 percent or 400 to 700 mL during pregnancy.
  • The respiratory rate is essentially unchanged, but tidal volume and resting minute ventilation increase significantly as pregnancy advances.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

questions.text: A 24 year old G1P0 woman presents to Obstetric OPD at 7 weeks of amenorrhoea with a positive UPT. The gynaecologist does a gentle bimanual examination (as shown below), and her abdominal & vaginal fingers seem to appose below the body of the uterus. Which clinical sign of pregnancy is being elicited here?
questions.solution:
• Hegar sign is a non-specific indication of pregnancy characterized by the compressibility & softening of the cervical isthmus.
  • It is elicited by doing a gentle bimanual examination, wherein the abdominal & vaginal fingers seem to appose just below the body of the uterus.
  • It can be demonstrated between 6 to 10 weeks of pregnancy, a little earlier in multiparae.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

questions.text: A 35 year old G3P2L2 woman presents at 34 weeks' gestation with pain & increasing swelling in her left leg. She has been experiencing it for 2 days now. Her pulse is 84/min, BP 124/82 mmHg, respiratory rate 16/min, temperature 98.6 F. There is pain in the calf and knee on dorsiflexion of left foot. Doppler ultrasound was ordered & labs reveal an elevated D-dimer level. Which of the following physiological changes increased her risk for the condition described above?
questions.solution:
Fibrinogen, a key protein in clot formation, increases during pregnancy, contributing to the hypercoagulable state and increased risk of thromboembolism.

  • The clinical presentation appears to be of Deep Venous Thrombosis of the left lower limb.
  • Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state & increases the risk of DVT.
  • During pregnancy, the production of fibrinogen is increased.
  • Homans' sign is considered to be a sign of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). It was defined by John Homans as discomfort behind the knee upon forced dorsiflexion of the foot.

Optionwise explanations:

  1. a) Increase in RBC mass: This occurs during pregnancy to improve oxygen-carrying capacity, but it does not directly increase the risk of DVT.
  2. c) Increase in ESR: While the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) rises during pregnancy, it is a nonspecific marker of inflammation and does not directly contribute to clot formation.
  3. d) Increase in protein C levels: Protein C is part of the body’s natural anticoagulant system. However, protein C activity decreases in pregnancy, which actually contributes to the hypercoagulable state. An increase in protein C would reduce the risk, not increase it.

KEY TAKE AWAY :-

  • Evidence of activation includes increased concentrations of all clotting factors except factors XI and XIII
  • Although somewhat conflicting, most evidence suggests that fibrinolytic activity is reduced in normal pregnancy
  • the Net result is that pregnancy is a procoagulant state. Amnionic fluid is a potent activation of coagulation

choices.text: Immunity mediated by T-helper (Th) 1 cells shifts to Th2-mediated immunity
The ratio of CD4 to CD8 T lymphocytes reverses
During labor and the early puerperium, leucocytosis is ≥25,000/ml
Immunoglobulin-rich cervical mucus plug creates a barrier to ascending infection

questions.text: All of the following immunological changes happen in pregnancy, except:
questions.solution:
The CD4/CD8 ratio does not reverse in pregnancy. Although there are slight immunological changes, the ratio generally remains stable or only slightly altered, without a full reversal.

Option-wise explanation:

a) Immunity mediated by T-helper (Th) 1 cells shifts to Th2-mediated immunity:

Correct. In pregnancy, there is a shift from a Th1-mediated (cellular) immune response to a Th2-mediated (humoral) immune response. This shift helps in maintaining immune tolerance towards the fetus.

c) During labor and the early puerperium, leucocytosis is ≥25,000/ml:

Correct. Leucocytosis, often with white blood cell counts exceeding 25,000/ml, is a common physiological response during labor and immediately after delivery.

d) Immunoglobulin-rich cervical mucus plug creates a barrier to ascending infection:

Correct. The cervical mucus plug, rich in immunoglobulins, forms a protective barrier that helps prevent ascending infections from reaching the uterine cavity during pregnancy.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • Normal leukocyte counts during pregnancy can be higher than nonpregnant values, and upper values approach 15,000/uL
  • Specifically, B lymphocytes numbers are unchanged, but the absolute numbers of T lymphocytes rise and create a relative increase.
  • Concurrently, the ratio of CD4 to CD8 T lymphocytes does not change

choices.text: Para amino hippuric acid excretion method

questions.text: Gold standard for estimation of GFR in pregnancy is:
questions.solution:
The 24-hour creatinine clearance is commonly used in clinical practice as a reliable and practical method for estimating glomerular filtration rate (GFR) in pregnancy. It accounts for physiological changes in renal function during pregnancy.

Option-wise explanation:

Correct.b) Inulin clearance method:
Incorrect. Although inulin clearance is considered the most accurate method to measure GFR, it is rarely used in clinical practice due to its complexity, especially in pregnant patients.

c) Cystatin C clearance method:
Incorrect. Cystatin C is a promising marker for GFR estimation, but it is not yet widely accepted as the gold standard, especially in pregnancy.

d) Para amino hippuric acid excretion method:
Incorrect. Para-amino hippuric acid (PAH) is used to estimate renal plasma flow (RPF) rather than GFR, and is not considered the standard for GFR estimation.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

choices.text: There is an increase in the production of thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG)
Increase in total T3 & total T4
Serum concentrations of TSH are increased slightly in the first trimester
Serum free T4 (fT4) and T3 (fT3) levels are slightly altered but are usually of no clinical significance

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding thyroid function in pregnancy:
questions.solution:
In the first trimester, TSH levels generally decrease due to the thyroid-stimulating effect of hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin), which shares structural similarity with TSH.

Option-wise explanation:

a) There is an increase in the production of thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG):
Correct. Estrogen increases the production of thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG) during pregnancy, leading to higher total T3 and T4 levels.

b) Increase in total T3 & total T4:
Correct. Due to the rise in TBG levels, there is an increase in total T3 and T4, though free levels of these hormones usually remain unchanged or slightly altered.

d) Serum free T4 (fT4) and T3 (fT3) levels are slightly altered but are usually of no clinical significance:
Correct. Free T4 and T3 levels may undergo slight alterations but typically remain within normal physiological ranges and are usually not of significant clinical concern.

KEY TAKE AWAY :-

Reference: Soma-Pillay P, Nelson-Piercy C. Physiological changes in pregnancy
